standard_metadata.standard_description: Understand addition and subtraction of fractions as joining and separating parts referring to the same whole.

images.alt: A number line labeled zero-halves to six-halves with tick marks at every one-half unit. A red dot is on two-halves. A green arrow starting at a green dot at five-halves moves left along the number line, pointing to the two-halves mark. Above the arrow is the label minus three-halves.

A number line labeled zero-thirds to six-thirds with tick marks every one-third unit. A red dot is at three-thirds. A green arrow starting at a blue dot at five-thirds moves left along the number line, pointing to tick mark three-thirds. Above the arrow is the label minus two-thirds.

A number line labeled zero-thirds to six-thirds with tick marks every one-third unit. A red dot is on four-thirds. A green arrow, starting at a blue dot at five-thirds, moves left along the number line, pointing to tick mark four-thirds. Above the arrow is the label minus one-third.

A number line labeled zero-fourths to four-fourths with tick marks every one-fourth unit. A red dot is at one-fourth. A green arrow starting at a blue dot at three-fourths moves left along the number line, pointing to tick mark one-fourth. Above the arrow is the label minus two-fourths.

A number line labeled zero-fourths to eight-fourths with tick marks every one-fourth unit. A red dot is at four-fourths. A green arrow starting at a blue dot at seven-fourths moves left along the number line, pointing to tick mark four-fourths. Above the arrow is the label minus three-fourths.

A number line labeled zero-fifths to five-fifths with tick marks every one-fifth unit. A red dot is at three-fifths. A green arrow starting at a blue dot at four-fifths moves left along the number line pointing to tick mark three-fifths. Above the arrow is the label minus one-fifth.

A number line labeled zero-fifths to ten-fifths with tick mark every one-fifth unit. A red dot is at six-fifths. A green arrow starting at a blue dot at eight-fifths moves left along the number line, pointing to tick mark six-fifths. Above the arrow is the label minus two-fifths.

A number line labeled zero-sixths to six-sixths with tick marks every one-sixth unit. A red dot is at one-sixth. A green arrow starting at a blue dot at three-sixths moves left along the number line pointing to tick mark one-sixth. Above the arrow is the label minus two-sixths.

A number line labeled zero-sixths to twelve-sixths with tick marks every one-sixth unit. A red dot is on five-sixths. A green arrow starting at a blue dot at ten-sixths moves left along the number line, pointing to the five-sixths tick mark. Above the arrow is the label minus five-sixths.

A number line labeled zero-eighths to eight-eighths with tick marks every one-eighth unit. A red dot appears at four-eighths. A green arrow starting at a blue dot at seven-eighths moves left along the number line, pointing to tick mark four-eighths. Above the arrow is the label minus three-eighths.

A number line labeled zero-eighths to sixteen-eighths with tick marks every one-eighth unit. A red dot is at seven-eighths. A green arrow starting at a blue dot at eleven-eighths moves left along the number line pointing to tick mark seven-eighths. Above the arrow is the label minus four-eighths.

A number line labeled zero-tenths to ten-tenths with tick marks every one-tenth unit. A red dot is on two-tenths. A green arrow starting at a blue dot at seven-tenths moves left along the number line, pointing to tick mark two-tenths. Above the arrow is the label minus five-tenths.

A number line labeled zero-tenths to twelve-tenths with tick marks every one-tenth unit. A red dot is on seven-tenths. A green arrow starting at a blue dot at eleven-tenths moves left along the number line, pointing to seven-tenths. Above the arrow is the label minus four-tenths.

A number line labeled zero-twelfths to twelve-twelfths with tick marks every one-twelfth unit. A red dot is at two-twelfths. A green arrow starting at a blue dot at four-twelfths moves left along the number line, pointing at tick mark two-twelfths. Above the arrow is the label minus two-twelfths.

A number line labeled zero-twelfths to twelve-twelfths with tick marks every one-twelfth unit. A red dot appears at seven-twelfths. A green arrow starting at a blue dot at eleven-twelfths moves left along the number line, pointing to tick mark seven-twelfths. Above the arrow is the label minus four-twelfths.

question.content: **Which of the following equations is true?**

hints.content: An equation is true when the left and right sides of the equal sign have the same value.  Let's compare the values of each side of the equations.
##Is $\dfrac8{10} - \dfrac2{10} = \dfrac{10}{10}$ true?   [[☃ image 1]]  $\blueD{\dfrac8{10}} - \greenD{\dfrac2{10}}$ equals $\maroonD{\dfrac6{10}}$, so the equation is *not* true.

images.alt: A number line labeled zero-tenths to ten-tenths with tick marks every one-tenth unit. A red dot is on six-tenths. A green arrow starting at a blue dot at eight-tenths moves left along the number line, pointing to the tick mark six-tenths. Above the arrow is the label minus two-tenths.

hints.content: ##Is $\dfrac4{12} - \dfrac3{12} = \dfrac2{12}$ true?    [[☃ image 1]]  $\blueD{\dfrac4{12}} - \greenD{\dfrac3{12}}$ equals $\maroonD{\dfrac1{12}}$, so the equation is *not* true.

images.alt: A number line labeled zero-twelfths to twelve-twelfths with tick marks every one-twelfth unit. A red dot appears at one-twelfth. A green arrow starting at a blue dot at four-twelfths moves left along the number line, pointing to tick mark one-twelfth. Above the arrow is the label minus three-twelfths.

hints.content: ##Is $\dfrac42 - \dfrac12 = \dfrac32$ true?    [[☃ image 1]]  $\blueD{\dfrac42} - \greenD{\dfrac12}$ equals $\maroonD{\dfrac32}$, so the equation *is* true.

images.alt: A number line labeled zero-halves to four-halves with tick marks every one-half unit. A red dot is on three-halves. A green arrow starting at a blue dot at four-halves moves left along the number line, pointing to tick mark three-halves. Above the arrow is the label minus one-half.

question.content: **Which of the following equations is true?**

hints.content: An equation is true when the left and right sides of the equal sign have the same value.  Let's compare the values of each side of the equations.
##Is $\dfrac35 - \dfrac25 = \dfrac55$ true?   [[☃ image 1]]  $\blueD{\dfrac35} - \greenD{\dfrac25}$ equals $\maroonD{\dfrac15}$, so the equation is *not* true.

images.alt: A number line labeled zero-fifths to five-fifths with tick marks every one-fifth unit. A red dot is on one-fifth. A green arrow starting at a blue dot at three-fifths moves left along the number line, pointing to the one-fifth marl. Above the arrow is the label minus two-fifths.

hints.content: ##Is $\dfrac46 - \dfrac36 = \dfrac1{12}$ true?   [[☃ image 1]]  $\blueD{\dfrac46} - \greenD{\dfrac36}$ equals $\maroonD{\dfrac1{6}}$, so the equation is *not* true.

images.alt: A number line labeled zero-sixths to six-sixths with tick marks every one-sixth unit. A red dot is on one-sixth. A green arrow starting at a blue dot at four-sixths moves left long the number line, pointing to the one-sixth mark. Above the arrow is the label minus three-sixths.

hints.content: ##Is $\dfrac73 - \dfrac23 = \dfrac53$ true?   [[☃ image 1]]  $\blueD{\dfrac73} - \greenD{\dfrac23}$ equals $\maroonD{\dfrac53}$, so the equation *is* true.

images.alt: A number line labeled zero-thirds to nine-thirds with tick marks at every one-third unit. A red dot is on five-thirds. A green arrow starting at a blue dot at seven-thirds moves left along the number line, pointing to the five-thirds mark. Above the arrow is the label minus two-thirds.

question.content: **Which of the following equations is true?**

hints.content: An equation is true when the left and right sides of the equal sign have the same value.  Let's compare the values of each side of the equations.
##Is $\dfrac32 - \dfrac12 = \dfrac42$ true?    [[☃ image 1]]  $\blueD{\dfrac32} - \greenD{\dfrac12}$ equals $\maroonD{\dfrac22}$, so the equation is *not* true.

images.alt: A number line labeled zero-halves to four-halves with tick marks every one-half unit. A red dot is on two-halves. A green arrow starting at a blue dot at three-halves moves left along the number line, pointing to three-halves. Above the arrow is the labeled minus one-half.

hints.content: ##Is $\dfrac88 - \dfrac28 = \dfrac48$ true?   [[☃ image 1]]  $\blueD{\dfrac88} - \greenD{\dfrac28}$ equals $\maroonD{\dfrac68}$, so the equation is *not* true.

images.alt: A number line labeled zero-eighths to eight-eighths with tick marks every one-eighth unit. A red dot is on six-eighths. A green arrow starting at a blue dot at eight-eighths moves left along the number line, pointing to the six-eighths mark. Above the number line is the label minus two-eighths.

hints.content: ##Is $\dfrac54 - \dfrac24 = \dfrac34$ true?  [[☃ image 1]]  $\blueD{\dfrac54} - \greenD{\dfrac24}$ equals $\maroonD{\dfrac34}$, so the equation *is* true.

images.alt: A number line labeled zero-fourths to eight-fourths with tick marks every one-fourth unit. A red dot is on three-fourths. A green arrow starting at a blue dot at five-fourths moves left along the number line, pointing to the three-fourths mark. Above the arrow is the label minus two-fourths.

question.content: **Which of the following equations is true?**

hints.content: An equation is true when the left and right sides of the equal sign have the same value.  Let's compare the values of each side of the equations.
##Is $\dfrac4{5}- \dfrac3{5} = \dfrac{7}{10}$ true?   [[☃ image 1]]  $\blueD{\dfrac4{5}} - \greenD{\dfrac3{5}}$ equals $\maroonD{\dfrac1{5}}$, so the equation is *not* true.

images.alt: A number line labeled zero-fifths to five-fifths with tick marks every one-fifth unit. A red dot is at one-fifths. A green arrow starting at a blue dot at four-fifths moves left along the number line, pointing to tick mark one-fifth. Above the arrow is the label minus three-fifths.

hints.content: ##Is $\dfrac4{3} - \dfrac2{3} = \dfrac2{6}$ true?    [[☃ image 1]]  $\blueD{\dfrac4{3}} - \greenD{\dfrac2{3}}$ equals $\maroonD{\dfrac2{3}}$, so the equation is *not* true.

images.alt: A number line labeled zero-thirds to six-thirds with tick marks every one-third unit. A red dot is at two-thirds. A green arrow starting at a blue dot at four-thirds moves left along the number line, pointing to tick mark two-thirds. Above the arrow is the label minus two-thirds.

hints.content: ##Is $\dfrac75 - \dfrac45 = \dfrac35$ true?    [[☃ image 1]]  $\blueD{\dfrac7{5}} - \greenD{\dfrac4{5}}$ equals $\maroonD{\dfrac3{5}}$, so the equation *is* true.

images.alt: A number line labeled zero-fifths to ten-fifths with tick marks every one-fifth unit. A red dot is at three-fifths. A green arrow starting at a blue dot at seven-fifths moves left along the number line, pointing to tick mark three-fifths. Above the arrow is the label minus four-fifths.

question.content: **Which of the following equations is true?**

hints.content: An equation is true when the left and right sides of the equal sign have the same value.  Let's compare the values of each side of the equations.
##Is $\dfrac34 - \dfrac14 = \dfrac{4}{4}$ true?    [[☃ image 1]]  $\blueD{\dfrac3{4}} - \greenD{\dfrac1{4}}$ equals $\maroonD{\dfrac2{4}}$, so the equation is *not* true.

images.alt: A number line labeled zero-fourths to four-fourths with tick marks every one-fourth unit. A red dot is on two-fourths. A green arrow starting at a blue dot at three-fourths moves left along the number line, pointing to the two-fourths mark. Above the arrow is the label minus one-fourth.

hints.content: ##Is $\dfrac4{2} - \dfrac2{2} = \dfrac2{4}$ true?    [[☃ image 1]]  $\blueD{\dfrac4{2}} - \greenD{\dfrac2{2}}$ equals $\maroonD{\dfrac2{2}}$, so the equation is *not* true.

images.alt: A number line labeled zero-halves to four-halves with tick marks at every one-half unit. A red dot is on two-halves. A green arrow starting at a blue dot at four-halves moves left along the number line pointing to the two-halves mark. Above the arrow is the labeled minus two-halves.

hints.content: ##Is $\dfrac56 - \dfrac36 = \dfrac26$ true?   [[☃ image 1]]  $\blueD{\dfrac5{6}} - \greenD{\dfrac3{6}}$ equals $\maroonD{\dfrac2{6}}$, so the equation *is* true.

images.alt: A number line labeled zero-sixths to six-sixths with tick marks at every one-sixth unit. A red dot is on two-sixths. A green arrow starting at a blue dot at five-sixths moves left along the number line, pointing to the two-sixths mark. Above the arrow is the labeled minus three-sixths.

question.content: **Which of the following equations is true?**

hints.content: An equation is true when the left and right sides of the equal sign have the same value.  Let's compare the values of each side of the equations.
##Is $\dfrac4{12} - \dfrac1{12} = \dfrac{5}{12}$ true?   [[☃ image 1]]  $\blueD{\dfrac4{12}} - \greenD{\dfrac1{12}}$ equals $\maroonD{\dfrac{3}{12}}$, so the equation is *not* true.

A green arrow starting at a blue dot at four-twelfths moves left along the number line, pointing to tick mark three-twelfths. Above the arrow is the label minus one-twelfth.

hints.content: ##Is $\dfrac4{3} - \dfrac2{3} = \dfrac2{6}$ true?    [[☃ image 1]]  $\blueD{\dfrac4{3}} - \greenD{\dfrac2{3}}$ equals $\maroonD{\dfrac2{3}}$, so the equation is *not* true.

images.alt: A number line labeled zero-thirds to six-thirds with tick marks every one-third unit. A red dot is at two-thirds. A green arrow starting at a blue dot at four-thirds moves left along the number line, pointing to tick mark two-thirds. Above the arrow is the label minus two-thirds.

hints.content: ##Is $\dfrac78 - \dfrac48 = \dfrac38$ true?    [[☃ image 1]]  $\blueD{\dfrac7{8}} - \greenD{\dfrac4{8}}$ equals $\maroonD{\dfrac3{8}}$, so the equation *is* true.

A green arrow starting at a blue dot at seven-eights moves left along the number line, pointing to tick mark three-eighths. Above the arrow is the label minus four-eighths.

##Is $\dfrac4{3} - \dfrac2{3} = \dfrac6{3}$ true?    [[☃ image 1]]  $\blueD{\dfrac4{3}} - \greenD{\dfrac2{3}}$ equals $\maroonD{\dfrac2{3}}$, so the equation is *not* true.
